brief_title: Asthma Phenotypes in the Inner City (APIC/ICAC-19)
description: This study looks to define the phenotypic characteristics of Difficult-to-Treat asthma, among 650 children between the ages of 6 to 17 years, receiving one year of guidelines-based therapy for asthma and rhinitis/rhinosinusitis.
endpoints: This study is not a clinical trial with a single disease outcome or endpoint. Our objective is to determine distinct characteristics that will discriminate Difficult-to-Treat from Easy-to-Treat asthmatic children in a variety of domains, and to identify specific phenotypes of Difficult-to-Treat asthma.
hypothesis: 1) The factors that we have chosen to test as partial predictors of treatment response will turn out to be predictors. 2) Difficult-to-Treat asthma is associated with Difficult-to-Treat rhinitis. 3) Difficult-to-Treat asthma is associated with a specific pattern of gene expression profiling in nasal epithelium.
objectives: The primary objective is to determine distinct characteristics that will discriminate Difficult-to-Treat from Easy-to-Treat phenotypes in a subject population adherent to study-directed asthma treatment and management. The secondary objectives are 1) To identify a set of asthma phenotypes using cluster analysis
